Situation1: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I was scrubbing the hallway floor, watching the dust swirl in the sunlight, when my phone buzzed. The message was urgent: the synagogue needed one more person for the minyan at a funeral prayer. My supervisor had just reminded me that the manager would be inspecting the rooms today, and I could see the dust gathering in the corners, the fingerprints on the glass. I knew what was expected of me here—every surface spotless, every room perfect. But the message tugged at me. As a Jew, I knew how important it was to help form the minyan, especially for a funeral prayer. Without me, the prayer couldn’t happen, and the grieving family would be left waiting. My mop dripped onto the floor as I stood frozen, torn between the demands of my job and the call of my faith. The clock ticked, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each expecting me to be present, each unwilling to wait.
